turn.label: Mr. Don Langston
turn.text: That's correct Your Honor.

The decision of the District Court on standards held that the Untied States Constitution did not make it necessary that trial courts in Arkansas charge or instruct juries regarding standards or guidelines to guide them in assessing life or death.

The court reasoned that Arkansas procedure, rested the decision, in the discretion of the jury to be exercised in the light of judgment, common sense, and experience of the jurors, and the jurors are presumed to be persons of good judgment and common sense.
We advance that argument here today also on the single verdict procedure, the District Court held that while some states may have split verdicts.
No court has held or it does not think that is constitutionally required that any court have a split verdict.
The decision of the Court of Appeals went along the same line.
It rejected the petitioner's contentions in these cases, and we recommend that opinion to this Court in deciding this case.

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: May I ask you of the definition, statutory definition of rape?
Is in your record somewhere, in Arkansas?

turn.speaker: don_langston
turn.label: Mr. Don Langston
turn.text: Yes sir, its defined in the jury instructions and --

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: But where is it in this record, do you know?

turn.speaker: don_langston
turn.label: Mr. Don Langston
turn.text: It would be in the jury instruction.
We have filed the transcript of the original case with this Court.
I suppose it still has it.
And the Court defines rape.

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: Is that in the same -- is that definition of rape in the same statute that fixes the punishment for rape?

turn.speaker: don_langston
turn.label: Mr. Don Langston
turn.text: I believe that they are separate Your Honor.

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: You don't know.

turn.speaker: don_langston
turn.label: Mr. Don Langston
turn.text: No, I don't recall, because we've changed our rape statute.

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: Well, could you mind letting us know?

turn.speaker: don_langston
turn.label: Mr. Don Langston
turn.text: Alright, Your Honor.
Since this case argued before this Court, some federal and state courts have decided that these two issues against the petitioner.
And we recommend those cases to the Court.
They are cited on pages 31 and 32 of petitioner's supplemental brief to enlarge the issues.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Can you weigh the jury trial on that application (Inaudible)?

turn.speaker: don_langston
turn.label: Mr. Don Langston
turn.text: No, Your Honor, it cannot.
If you plead guilty, the jury has to be impaneled and the state puts on a prima facie case.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Of guilt?

turn.speaker: don_langston
turn.label: Mr. Don Langston
turn.text: Of guilt, yes, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: And what do you do about that, if there's a plea of guilty, then there is a jury convened, do you have to put on a prima facie case of guilty?
But does it go any farther in that case and does it move for a trial, in terms of the factors that goes with the penalty?

turn.speaker: don_langston
turn.label: Mr. Don Langston
turn.text: Ordinarily, the trial would be very short and just enough -- ordinarily, it would be probably the fact that in a murder case that a murder has occurred, and that the defendant has confessed to it.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: What's that -- how do you view Arkansas' theory of punishment in this type of a case?
Does the jury question and decide the penalty base on acts of a crime only?
I suppose -- or at least the facts that come out in connection with this deciding guilt or innocence.

turn.speaker: don_langston
turn.label: Mr. Don Langston
turn.text: I think those factors are quite an effort for the jury to make an intelligent position on punishment.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well, yes but what is the -- do you think that the jury should confine itself to that?

turn.speaker: don_langston
turn.label: Mr. Don Langston
turn.text: That's our position, yes, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well, what if -- what if in a non-capital case, where -- does the judge ever sentence in Arkansas for certain -- for felonies?

turn.speaker: don_langston
turn.label: Mr. Don Langston
turn.text: In felonies, only in cases where the jury cannot agree, then he can set the punishment.
What they had --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: And when he does so, do you have the presentence reports?

turn.speaker: don_langston
turn.label: Mr. Don Langston
turn.text: No, your Honor, we do not.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: You just go on the record displayed on presenting guilt or on a deciding guilt or innocence?

turn.speaker: don_langston
turn.label: Mr. Don Langston
turn.text: That's correct.
What happens is the jury goes out and decides guilt and then it reports back to the judge that it has decided on guilt or innocence, but cannot reach a verdict on punishment.
Then the judge takes the case -- he takes the verdict of guilt, then he sets the punishment -- punishment within statutory limits.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: And all he knows is what's in the transcript.

turn.speaker: don_langston
turn.label: Mr. Don Langston
turn.text: What's he's heard is what the jury has heard.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: So there are no presentence reports or -- in Arkansas?

turn.speaker: don_langston
turn.label: Mr. Don Langston
turn.text: There is a statute in Arkansas that whenever a person is sentenced to the penitentiary that there will be -- the judge will send along with the prisoner his remarks, the prosecuting attorney will send his remarks along with it.
It sort of a presentence report, but --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well, I know but it isn't used for the purpose of deciding the length of time, where which the person is committed to a prison.

turn.speaker: don_langston
turn.label: Mr. Don Langston
turn.text: That is correct.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Mr. Langston, is there any allocution out in Arkansas at all?

turn.speaker: don_langston
turn.label: Mr. Don Langston
turn.text: There might -- could be some, under the statute that we have cited if when the defendant would file a motion for a new trial, which is the overruling of this motion is what you appeal from in Arkansas is from a motion, from the denial of your motion for new trial.
He may -- if the judge in his discretion wants to, he may hear some evidence in allocution, but I don't think it's very common in Arkansas.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Did you not required?

turn.speaker: don_langston
turn.label: Mr. Don Langston
turn.text: That's correct.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: And Arkansas does not normally give any instruction on this regarding race?

turn.speaker: don_langston
turn.label: Mr. Don Langston
turn.text: No, Your Honor, it do not.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: And so, they don't give any instructions on the proper person to be sentenced to the proper number of years or anything at all in that sense?

turn.speaker: don_langston
turn.label: Mr. Don Langston
turn.text: That's correct.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: And that's left after the “untrammeled discretion” of the jury?

turn.speaker: don_langston
turn.label: Mr. Don Langston
turn.text: Ordinarily, they --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: And is it true that under the law of Arkansas, a juror can use any whim he wants?

turn.speaker: don_langston
turn.label: Mr. Don Langston
turn.text: It's an unfettered discretion.
Ordinarily the judge instructs them on --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Well, how could you find -- you agreed that you can normally find abuse of discretion from a judge, can't you?
Was there in anyway to find abuse of discretion from the jury?

turn.speaker: don_langston
turn.label: Mr. Don Langston
turn.text: I doubt it, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: I kind of hope this isn't.

turn.speaker: don_langston
turn.label: Mr. Don Langston
turn.text: I didn't get your last word?

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: I kind of hope this isn't.

turn.speaker: don_langston
turn.label: Mr. Don Langston
turn.text: Well, we think that discretion of the jury is a good thing.

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: I presume that there were facts in this case, from which the jury can discern itself about it, was there none?

turn.speaker: don_langston
turn.label: Mr. Don Langston
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: But what were those facts that cause the jury, it must have been something that do with the jury sentencing to death.
How did this crime occur?

turn.speaker: don_langston
turn.label: Mr. Don Langston
turn.text: Your Honor, in the early morning hours on November 3, 1961, the defendant, the white woman, 35-year-old white woman, living with her invalid 90-year-old father, heard someone trying to break in to their house.
She went to the door and told the man to leave, and said she would call the police.
He had a stocking he was trying to pull down over his head.

So, he wouldn't -- he kept advancing toward her, so she got on the telephone, and got the operator, who when the man attacked the woman, she started screaming, so the operator connected the telephone with the police, and the police heard the screams over the telephone and they were struggling there.
Her invalid father came in to assist her.
The defendant put his hand over her mouth, she bit his finger, and bit his hand.

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: Bit whose finger?

turn.speaker: don_langston
turn.label: Mr. Don Langston
turn.text: Bit the defendant's finger and his hand.
His father could not help her, so he went to the window and started yelling for help.
Of course, the police were trying to locate where the telephone call is coming from.
So the defendant then dragged the victim from her house, down the street to up of embankment, up to a vacant lot.
There were cuts and bruises on her feet, she was in her pajamas.
And there were cuts all over and they struggling up there in the lot, and he threatened to kill her, if she told, and that's basically the facts.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: What about the attack on the father?
You referred that before, that he was beaten.

turn.speaker: don_langston
turn.label: Mr. Don Langston
turn.text: He beat the father too, and so the father said, “I just can't help you anymore,” and so went to the window and tried to yell for help.
And he dragged the victim out from the house.

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: Well, how did he beat the father in what way?

turn.speaker: don_langston
turn.label: Mr. Don Langston
turn.text: Just his fist.

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: How old was her father?

turn.speaker: don_langston
turn.label: Mr. Don Langston
turn.text: 90 years old.
And he was an invalid.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Was he killed?

turn.speaker: don_langston
turn.label: Mr. Don Langston
turn.text: No, sir.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Tell me, what -- seems your statute, as I understand, puts all criminal offenses in the hands of the jury in sentencing, is that right?

turn.speaker: don_langston
turn.label: Mr. Don Langston
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Does that mean that there's no allocution anymore in Arkansas at all?

turn.speaker: don_langston
turn.label: Mr. Don Langston
turn.text: That's correct.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: What about the situation, where you say a non-capital case, if I understood correctly, the jury can't agree on the penalty, perhaps that's true also in the capital cases.
What happens then?
Does the judge fix the sentence?

turn.speaker: don_langston
turn.label: Mr. Don Langston
turn.text: That's correct.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: So that in this case, if the jury said they couldn't agree on life or death, the judge would have fixed the sentence?

turn.speaker: don_langston
turn.label: Mr. Don Langston
turn.text: No, Your Honor, he can't do that in capital cases, you cannot do that.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: In non-capital case you can't.

turn.speaker: don_langston
turn.label: Mr. Don Langston
turn.text: That's correct.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Now, what happens in those situations?
Is it under your statute, does the defendant have a right of allocution?

turn.speaker: don_langston
turn.label: Mr. Don Langston
turn.text: I don't believe so, Your Honor.
I don't know of any -- I do not know of any case that would hold that.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Your allocution statute is in relative, is it as far as having any applications for this case?

turn.speaker: don_langston
turn.label: Mr. Don Langston
turn.text: I believe your correct.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: It's still on the books.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Well, it applies only to cases where the sentence is fix by the judge, is that what you're telling us?

turn.speaker: don_langston
turn.label: Mr. Don Langston
turn.text: Your Honor, I don't believe that they have any allocution in our state courts.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Even when the judge sentences?

turn.speaker: don_langston
turn.label: Mr. Don Langston
turn.text: That's correct.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: But you've got a statute, haven't you?

turn.speaker: don_langston
turn.label: Mr. Don Langston
turn.text: I wasn't aware of it, Mr. Amsterdam we do, but I wasn't aware of the allocation statute.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Haven't you looked up and I thought you have?
As you just told me, maybe that's wrong.

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: Have you read the statute to which you refer us now?

turn.speaker: don_langston
turn.label: Mr. Don Langston
turn.text: I do not -- I didn't -- I don't know of the statute that says.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Aren't you familiar enough for the day-to-day practice, so that you can say you -- that you know the right is not accorded to a defendant, when the judge is sentencing?

turn.speaker: don_langston
turn.label: Mr. Don Langston
turn.text: I know that -- I've tried some criminal cases and it's never done.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: You mean he's never asked the defendant to say anything, in connection with his (Voice Overlap).

turn.speaker: don_langston
turn.label: Mr. Don Langston
turn.text: Well, whatever he sentence -- whenever he sentences, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: I'm not talking about a formal allocution, do you mean that he never, the judge who tries a man, before he sentence him, never asked him or gives him a chance to say anything about it at all?

turn.speaker: don_langston
turn.label: Mr. Don Langston
turn.text: Your Honor, he brings in a judgment, if the judge is trying it himself, trial before the court, he brings in the judgment.
Of course, and he waits the statutory, the limit of time before he sentences him, then he does asked him he has anything to say in his behalf or nearly nothing he's saying.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Oh!
That's the allocution.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: That's allocution.
He does ask?

turn.speaker: don_langston
turn.label: Mr. Don Langston
turn.text: Yes, yes sir.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Is he required to do that by your statute?

turn.speaker: don_langston
turn.label: Mr. Don Langston
turn.text: I don't think so, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: But it is regularly done?

turn.speaker: don_langston
turn.label: Mr. Don Langston
turn.text: Yes, sir.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: And what is -- is there a time lag that the judgments wait before he sentences?

turn.speaker: don_langston
turn.label: Mr. Don Langston
turn.text: 48 hours.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: 48 hours.

turn.speaker: don_langston
turn.label: Mr. Don Langston
turn.text: Of course, this can --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: I don't get this Mr. Langston.
You say it's regularly done, but it's never done in the jury, where the jury fixes.

turn.speaker: don_langston
turn.label: Mr. Don Langston
turn.text: By statute in Arkansas, you have to wait 48 hours before you can sentence a person --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: No, no, but were the jury fixes the sentence?

turn.speaker: don_langston
turn.label: Mr. Don Langston
turn.text: The jury fixes the sentence, I mean the jury fixes the punishment, the judgment is in and on that verdict and then --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: There's no allocution then, well is it?

turn.speaker: don_langston
turn.label: Mr. Don Langston
turn.text: No, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: I think that answer came in response to my question, Mr. Justice Brennan, relating to non-jury penalty.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Where juries had been waived, is that it?
You're just talking about bench trials now, are you?

turn.speaker: don_langston
turn.label: Mr. Don Langston
turn.text: Yes, sir.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Not jury trials?

turn.speaker: don_langston
turn.label: Mr. Don Langston
turn.text: No, they always asked them.
The judge always asked, whenever he sentences in any trial, he ask if he has anything to say before sentence is passed.

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: And does he have a mo -- does he have a right to make a motion, a new trial?

turn.speaker: don_langston
turn.label: Mr. Don Langston
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: On what ground?

turn.speaker: don_langston
turn.label: Mr. Don Langston
turn.text: There are several, newly discovered evidence, any errors occurred during trial.

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: They have a right to make a motion for new trial and now they get before the jury?

turn.speaker: don_langston
turn.label: Mr. Don Langston
turn.text: And put on evidence.

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: And argued that it was wrong thing and erroneous to convict him or sentence at all?

turn.speaker: don_langston
turn.label: Mr. Don Langston
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Mr. Langston I'm confused.
The jury finds a man guilty of crime of robbery and fixes the sentence of 20 years.
And the judge calls him in and said, “Do you have anything to say?”
Well, what can the judge do, regardless of what the man says?

turn.speaker: don_langston
turn.label: Mr. Don Langston
turn.text: Of course, he could set the verdict decide if he desires.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Well, what is the reason for saying, “What do you have to say before I give you the sentence, which I'm going to give you?”

turn.speaker: don_langston
turn.label: Mr. Don Langston
turn.text: Your Honor, I just know that that's done.
I don't know that it has any effect at all or (Voice Overlap).

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: What effect?
I'm asking you what effect could it have.

turn.speaker: don_langston
turn.label: Mr. Don Langston
turn.text: I suppose that anything he said that would be relevant to his sentence could be said.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Well, the judge couldn't change the sentence, does he?

turn.speaker: don_langston
turn.label: Mr. Don Langston
turn.text: The 43-2310 says, that if the judge, in cases of conviction, doesn't think that the punishment sentence is correct, he has the power to reduce the extent or duration of the sentence.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Well, then the jury doesn't then finally fix the sentence?

turn.speaker: don_langston
turn.label: Mr. Don Langston
turn.text: In effect, in Arkansas the jury it does.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: I'd understood that was a dead letter in that statute.

turn.speaker: don_langston
turn.label: Mr. Don Langston
turn.text: As far as I know what's never been interpreted --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: That was my understanding from the last argument.

turn.speaker: don_langston
turn.label: Mr. Don Langston
turn.text: Yes, sir.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: You mean it's in the statute, but judges never exercised that already (Inaudible)?

turn.speaker: don_langston
turn.label: Mr. Don Langston
turn.text: Your Honor, it's never been interpreted by our Supreme Court --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: It's never been interpreted, but it hasn't ever been used to your knowledge, by trial judge to change the sentence imposed by a jury?

turn.speaker: don_langston
turn.label: Mr. Don Langston
turn.text: I haven't found any cases on it, but I have been told by some judges that it has been done.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: That it has been done?

turn.speaker: don_langston
turn.label: Mr. Don Langston
turn.text: Yes, sir.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: And so the judge has the right to reset the punishment?
That he doesn't agree with the jury?

turn.speaker: don_langston
turn.label: Mr. Don Langston
turn.text: That's correct.
Your Honor.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: The judge could that on a motion for a new trial, couldn't he?

turn.speaker: don_langston
turn.label: Mr. Don Langston
turn.text: I believe he could, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: But he can't do it a capital case?
In a capital case, he can't do it, that I understood you to say?

turn.speaker: don_langston
turn.label: Mr. Don Langston
turn.text: I am advised that it has been done but the case didn't go to the Supreme Court, maybe there was something in the trial that the judge was -- I don't know what it could have occurred during the trial, but the judge thought on motion of the defendant that he should reduce it from death down to life, and that it has been done.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Did he do it in this case?

turn.speaker: don_langston
turn.label: Mr. Don Langston
turn.text: No, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Did he give him any chance to speak in this case, after the jury came in?

turn.speaker: don_langston
turn.label: Mr. Don Langston
turn.text: I don't recall whether he did or not.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Mr. Langston, what you said is so, we got a very different case here, and I thought we have.

You see if I get this correctly, are you telling us that under your statutes, the trial judge if they're satisfied with the sentence imposed by the jury, whether the case is a capital or a non capital case, can change the jury sentence?

turn.speaker: don_langston
turn.label: Mr. Don Langston
turn.text: That's what the statute it appears to say, Your Honor, 43-2310.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Would you read that to us, so we can get it before us.
Do you mind Mr. Justice Brennan?

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: I wish he would.

turn.speaker: don_langston
turn.label: Mr. Don Langston
turn.text: The court shall have power in all cases of conviction to reduce the extent or duration of the punishment assessed by the jury.

If in the opinion of the court, the conviction is proper, and the punishment assessed is greater than under the circumstances of the case, ought to be inflicted, so that the punishment be not, in any case, reduced below the limit prescribed by law in such cases.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well, that seems that a face value would seem to judge the right but didn't agree with the juries' death sentence, then he can set it aside.

turn.speaker: don_langston
turn.label: Mr. Don Langston
turn.text: That's what I argued the last time we were up here, but there's been no interpretation by our Supreme Court of this statute.
And it would appear on its face, to allow him to reduce the verdict --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well, that is a great deal of evidence.[Laughter]

turn.speaker: don_langston
turn.label: Mr. Don Langston
turn.text: I don't know of any one, Your Honor.
I don't know of any Supreme, Arkansas Supreme Court cases on it.
And the only way you could do it was probably to survey the -- make a survey of the Circuit Judges in Arkansas, and see if they have ever done it, the current ones.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well, that's what the statute seem to say on its face?

turn.speaker: don_langston
turn.label: Mr. Don Langston
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: And then, do you know whether a judge -- even if he didn't reset the sentence, if he disagreed with it he can order a new trial, because he thought the sentence was improper?

turn.speaker: don_langston
turn.label: Mr. Don Langston
turn.text: I think he could, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: If you think he could, how about the practice?
Do you know if it's ever done, that the judge says I'm dissatisfied with the sentence and I would modify it?

turn.speaker: don_langston
turn.label: Mr. Don Langston
turn.text: I would think if he were only dissatisfied with the sentence, he would just modify it and not have a complete trial.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: But there's no -- there's no provision in Arkansas for a judge giving a new trial only on the penalty.
If he disagrees with the penalty, he'd either got to set it or order a compete new trial?

turn.speaker: don_langston
turn.label: Mr. Don Langston
turn.text: I would believe so, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well, I'm waiting.
Is that right?
You just told us under that statute, if death was imposed under that statute, the judge fix it at light, instead.
Is that you contend?

turn.speaker: don_langston
turn.label: Mr. Don Langston
turn.text: That's my interpretation of the statute.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: He doesn't have to order a new trial?

turn.speaker: don_langston
turn.label: Mr. Don Langston
turn.text: No, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: He doesn't have to because if he didn't want to take the responsibility himself I suppose he would -- his only alternative would be to order a new trial completely because he couldn't order death penalt

turn.speaker: don_langston
turn.label: Mr. Don Langston
turn.text: That's correct.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: When was the statute enacted?

turn.speaker: don_langston
turn.label: Mr. Don Langston
turn.text: I suppose, it's been in the revised statutes, Chapter 45, so it's -- it is as old as the -- I imagine it was back whenever the Arkansas came into the union.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: And you -- you don't have any idea and you're attorney general -- Deputy Attorney General, and you've never heard of it, of every being used?

turn.speaker: don_langston
turn.label: Mr. Don Langston
turn.text: That's correct.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: And you know it's never interpreted?

turn.speaker: don_langston
turn.label: Mr. Don Langston
turn.text: It's never been interpreted by the Supreme Court.
I have been advised that a case -- that the Circuit Judge has reduced them, one from death to life.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Once.
In the whole history of the state?

turn.speaker: don_langston
turn.label: Mr. Don Langston
turn.text: That's all I know of, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Is there any procedure under your statutes, where it really doubt about those things?
This Court could ask for a certificate in the Arkansas court, what that statute mean?

turn.speaker: don_langston
turn.label: Mr. Don Langston
turn.text: I don't --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Is there such a procedure in some states, others are barred and we reserved it a couple of times, have you got anything like that in your state?

turn.speaker: don_langston
turn.label: Mr. Don Langston
turn.text: Not that I know of, our Supreme Court has held in its decision, if it does not give advisory opinions, only when there's a case or controversy.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Can a judge set a judgment aside?
I presume he can, I think -- I thought he could never stay in the union.

turn.speaker: don_langston
turn.label: Mr. Don Langston
turn.text: Yes sir, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: The only ground that it's run through it, are the weight of the evidence.
Can he set aside a conviction on the ground that's been run through the weight of the evidence, and se aside this sentence?

turn.speaker: don_langston
turn.label: Mr. Don Langston
turn.text: I think he can, your Honor.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: You think?
You don't know it?

turn.speaker: don_langston
turn.label: Mr. Don Langston
turn.text: I know he can, yes sir.
The Supreme Court of Arkansas as the petitioner's cited in his brief says that the Supreme Court of Arkansas can set aside a death verdict whenever there's not enough evidence to support it.
But just ordinarily, they can't do like -- the statute here says, they have said that they themselves do not have the power, unless the evidence is not enough to support the change --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Well, that's conferred on the weight of the evidence.

turn.speaker: don_langston
turn.label: Mr. Don Langston
turn.text: That's correct.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: But you talked about not enough evidence to support a death penalty.
Do you mean not enough evidence to support rape one?

turn.speaker: don_langston
turn.label: Mr. Don Langston
turn.text: Those cases --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: You mean it's enough to support the judgment, not the sentence?

turn.speaker: don_langston
turn.label: Mr. Don Langston
turn.text: Yes, sir.

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: Well, a sentence without a judgment wouldn't be worthless, would it?

turn.speaker: don_langston
turn.label: Mr. Don Langston
turn.text: That's correct.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Well, isn't under the Arkansas statute, isn't this sentence part of the judgment, when the jury has made a combined verdict of guilty and fix the penalty?
You don't have two documents for the judgment, do you?

turn.speaker: don_langston
turn.label: Mr. Don Langston
turn.text: No, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Just one judgment which is --

turn.speaker: don_langston
turn.label: Mr. Don Langston
turn.text: The court enters judgment upon the verdict of the jury, which is entered.
Mr. Justice White asked Mr. Amsterdam, concerning other felonies or other criminals conduct in Arkansas standards.

We believe that in this particular case, that to accept their argument, that standards must be applied in capital punishment or life imprisonment cases that are set for the jury that the court would have no alternative, but to order standards in, say cases of larceny or burglary, and Arkansas burglary is 2 to 21 years, larceny is 1 to 21 years.
We can see if the Court accepts it here that they could perhaps -- they would perhaps -- the next step would be to put in those types of cases.
And we would -- in Arkansas, of course, we would almost have to try every one of our cases over again.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Because if jury sentence it in all felony cases?

turn.speaker: don_langston
turn.label: Mr. Don Langston
turn.text: Yes, sir.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Unless, the jury is waived?

turn.speaker: don_langston
turn.label: Mr. Don Langston
turn.text: That's correct, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: And, in non-capital cases, you can waive the jury?

turn.speaker: don_langston
turn.label: Mr. Don Langston
turn.text: That's correct.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: And tried by the judge, then judge sentence it?

turn.speaker: don_langston
turn.label: Mr. Don Langston
turn.text: Yes, sir.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: But in those cases, as I understand you, the judge sentences only on the record that's made in determining guilty or innocent.

turn.speaker: don_langston
turn.label: Mr. Don Langston
turn.text: That's correct.

Only single verdict procedure, the way I gathered from the petitioner's argument, he is saying that either one he would have a separate penalty trial with the same jury or two, he would have a separate jury for penalty, or three, that he would have the judge set the penalty after a hearing on allocution.
We submit that this Court has never held that any states should have to have a double jury, have a double hearing on this particular aspect or case.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Tell Mr. Langston, of course, this petitioner did not take the stand, did he?

turn.speaker: don_langston
turn.label: Mr. Don Langston
turn.text: That's correct.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: When -- in your experience, when an accused does take a stand, what's the scope of the cross-examination permitted the prosecutor?

turn.speaker: don_langston
turn.label: Mr. Don Langston
turn.text: He is treated as any other witness would be, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: What's that mean?

turn.speaker: don_langston
turn.label: Mr. Don Langston
turn.text: He can be asked about the prior acts of misconduct, felony convictions, and things of that nature.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Not alone prior convictions, but also prior acts of misconduct, whether or not they resulted in prosecutions or crime?

turn.speaker: don_langston
turn.label: Mr. Don Langston
turn.text: That's correct, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Is there any cautionary instruction?

turn.speaker: don_langston
turn.label: Mr. Don Langston
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Even it would --

turn.speaker: don_langston
turn.label: Mr. Don Langston
turn.text: The judge gives a cautionary instruction that is only to go to test his credibility as a witness.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: But it's just not limited then to prior convictions of crime, but any acts of misconduct all his life?

turn.speaker: don_langston
turn.label: Mr. Don Langston
turn.text: That's my understanding of the law, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Well, I mean may a prosecutor exist without knowledge of any actual acts misconduct, employ a form of examination to enlist it?
Did you ever get into trouble before, that you ever get the trouble in school, all that sort of thing?

turn.speaker: don_langston
turn.label: Mr. Don Langston
turn.text: If the defendant answers in the negative, that ends the matter though, Your Honor.
He can't come back and introduce independent evidence that he did, do these acts.
He must take his answer.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: He's made his witness for that purpose?

turn.speaker: don_langston
turn.label: Mr. Don Langston
turn.text: That's correct, he must take his answer, he cannot come back and introduce, he can ask him if he's been convicted of a felony, excuse me, has been guilty of acts of misconduct, if he denies, and said he did not, and he can't bring in a witness and say, “Yes, he did do it.”

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: But, the prosecutor says, “Do you ever engage in a demonstration against the Vietnam War?”

turn.speaker: don_langston
turn.label: Mr. Don Langston
turn.text: These -- the cases in Arkansas sort of go more to acts of misconduct, toward moral turpitude than anything else.
Like indecent conduct or things of that nature.
I believe --

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: Is there anything like that been asked in this case?
Not the Vietnam War?

turn.speaker: don_langston
turn.label: Mr. Don Langston
turn.text: The defendant did not take the stand, Your Honor in this case.

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: Did the state trying to bring anything like that in at all?

turn.speaker: don_langston
turn.label: Mr. Don Langston
turn.text: No, Your Honor.
I believe I turn the rest the case over to Mr. Harris.

section.heading: Argument of Albert W. Harris, Jr.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Mr. Harris.

turn.speaker: albert_w_harris_jr
turn.label: Mr. Albert W. Harris, Jr.
turn.text: Mr. Chief Justice, and may it please the Court.
The interest of California in this case is a fairly narrow one, in terms of the questions that were -- or the issues that was set forth by Mr. Amsterdam at the start of his argument.

We are not concerned about the single verdict procedure, because we have in common with a number of other states, a bifurcated trial, and we have separate verdicts for both guilt and a verdict for the penalty in capital cases only.
Otherwise, almost all sentencing in California is by the judge and usually where the presentence report and all a number of other things.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: How many states, besides California have different theory based on the evidence, with reference to guilt and the reference to sentence presented?

turn.speaker: albert_w_harris_jr
turn.label: Mr. Albert W. Harris, Jr.
turn.text: Mr. Justice Black, first of all we don't have a different jury.
It's normally the same jury.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: On a different trial?

turn.speaker: albert_w_harris_jr
turn.label: Mr. Albert W. Harris, Jr.
turn.text: But it's a different trial.
It's a different face of the trial.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Well, how many states, besides California do that?

turn.speaker: albert_w_harris_jr
turn.label: Mr. Albert W. Harris, Jr.
turn.text: I don't know categorically, Your Honor.
I think Mr. Amsterdam said about eight this morning, and I would accept that as an accurate statement.

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: Has there been any change in California law since the Henderson opinion?

turn.speaker: albert_w_harris_jr
turn.label: Mr. Albert W. Harris, Jr.
turn.text: Well, there are always changes in California law, Your Honor but --

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: I mean that decision hasn't been qualified or modified or--?

turn.speaker: albert_w_harris_jr
turn.label: Mr. Albert W. Harris, Jr.
turn.text: No, I don't believe that it has, at least nothing connects at the moment.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: I take it Mr. Harris, if the defendant takes that stand at the guilt side or he cannot, a cross-examination be asked about as an Arkansas acts of misconduct of prior convictions, and that sort of thing?

turn.speaker: albert_w_harris_jr
turn.label: Mr. Albert W. Harris, Jr.
turn.text: No, he can only be asked the same questions as any other witness could be asked.
He could be asked about a prior felony, and so far as that would impeach his credibility.
He could be asked about questions that might reflect on bias and so forth, but he couldn't be asked generally about prior misconduct.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: But he could be asked about prior convictions?

turn.speaker: albert_w_harris_jr
turn.label: Mr. Albert W. Harris, Jr.
turn.text: Well, to impeach his credibility, any witness can about it, with a prior felony conviction in California.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: So, he's up against the same difficulty, about taking the stand then as sort of --

turn.speaker: albert_w_harris_jr
turn.label: Mr. Albert W. Harris, Jr.
turn.text: No, I don't think he's up to the -- anywhere near the same difficulty.
He doesn't have to take the stand in the guilt phase, of course, no comment can be made on if he doesn't.
He can take the stand in a penalty phase, after guilt has already been determine, and give whatever explanation he has.
By the same token, the people can show in that proceeding, anything in his history a background that in their judgment reflects adversely on it.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: No, but I mean, he does -- he is -- has something with dilemma at the guilt trial, whether or not to take the stand if he is previously been convicted of the crime, does he?

turn.speaker: albert_w_harris_jr
turn.label: Mr. Albert W. Harris, Jr.
turn.text: Well, that's true and that's true and that's true of any witness who might be called by anyone.
He's subject to cross examination, and his credibility has to be assessed, just like any other witness' credibility.

But we don't have any special rules as to criminal defendants, except that I think there's more of a tendency to limit cross-examinations, so you don't get beyond the scope of what he has waived by taking the stand.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: And that the guilt -- that the penalty phase, the state can introduce prior conduct, whether the defendant takes the stand or not.

turn.speaker: albert_w_harris_jr
turn.label: Mr. Albert W. Harris, Jr.
turn.text: That's correct your Honor, the state can prove prior crimes, if they do, they have to prove them beyond a reasonable doubt, the juries so instructed and things of that nature.
Now, we are also not concern with the Witherspoon question, as that has been presented here, leaving that to the parties.

Our interest in this case, and the reason we're appearing here is solely on the question of whether the Constitution somehow requires the juries be given some limiting and restricting standards in deciding on the question of whether life imprisonment or a death sentence should be imposed in capital cases.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: You mean some standards in addition, the standards they have set out to finding the crime.

turn.speaker: albert_w_harris_jr
turn.label: Mr. Albert W. Harris, Jr.
turn.text: That's correct, Your Honor, those standards of course, are very clear and specific as to whether or not there is a murder on the first degree.
I presume a rape in Arkansas or whatever the crime might be.
These would be standards, and really limitations and restrictions going solely to the question of penalty, having nothing to do with guilt, that having been determined already by definition.
It's done formally in California, in Arkansas it isn't and I don't want to enter in that dispute.
I would like to clarify one point, because of the national implications that were made clear by Mr. Amsterdam, and that's another reason why we're here.

In California, there is a process, by which the judge can pass in his discretion, and it's the same kind of absolute discretion without reference to any formal standards that the jury is suppose to exercise.

One there has been a death penalty, and he can if he sees fit in light of all the evidence, all of the factors that are involved, reduce it to a life sentence, and there it is forevermore a life sentence.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: That is the trial judge?

turn.speaker: albert_w_harris_jr
turn.label: Mr. Albert W. Harris, Jr.
turn.text: That is the trial judge.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: In his discretion without giving any reasons of any kind.

turn.speaker: albert_w_harris_jr
turn.label: Mr. Albert W. Harris, Jr.
turn.text: He doesn't have to give any reasons and probably it's better if he didn't, but he has the same scope of discretion that the jury has, that's my point, there is judicial review at the trial level.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: General has -- when in the appellate don't they have right too?
It's easy for me, we saw one recently.

turn.speaker: albert_w_harris_jr
turn.label: Mr. Albert W. Harris, Jr.
turn.text: No, Your Honor, the appellate court can of course, find for example the evidence isn't sufficient for murder in the first degree, and so it make it murder second.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: That's right.

turn.speaker: albert_w_harris_jr
turn.label: Mr. Albert W. Harris, Jr.
turn.text: But they have said, although it was – Justice Peters of the court takes a counter review that they will not, as a matter of discretion and judgment reduce a death sentence to a life sentence.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: But what they often do, in my observation, perhaps I'm dreaming, is to affirm the conviction that set aside the death sentence imposed in the penalty phase of the trial, because of error occurring in that phase of the trial.

turn.speaker: albert_w_harris_jr
turn.label: Mr. Albert W. Harris, Jr.
turn.text: That very commonly occurred, your Honor.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: I thought so.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Then, you get a new jury?

turn.speaker: albert_w_harris_jr
turn.label: Mr. Albert W. Harris, Jr.
turn.text: Pardon me, Your Honor?

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Then when it goes back, you have a different jury?

turn.speaker: albert_w_harris_jr
turn.label: Mr. Albert W. Harris, Jr.
turn.text: That's correct, you have a different jury or you can waive a jury if he's so inclined, provided the people way of his wealth.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: I suppose, for this absolute unreviewable discretion of the trial judge to reduce from death to a life sentence, this mean of course, that if there are some judges who have conscientious objections, and scruples about the death penalty, they would set aside death penalties more readily and no one could review that, is that correct?
No one can question the judge about his decisions.

turn.speaker: albert_w_harris_jr
turn.label: Mr. Albert W. Harris, Jr.
turn.text: No one can question the judge, in terms of an appeal from his judgment, that's correct Your Honor.
Now, there may be some questions --

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: I suppose I could some of Mr. Amsterdam's arguments that bartered on unequal protection to now with equal protection might reach your situation too, for such similar case here today, so I won't burden you with it.

turn.speaker: albert_w_harris_jr
turn.label: Mr. Albert W. Harris, Jr.
turn.text: No, it's a -- I think there's another facet of the situation in California, as well, that distinguishes it from a single verdict situation and meet some of the objections that have been raised here, and that is the objection generally that -- what the jury does on penalties is an uninformed judgment, maybe it's arbitrary, maybe it's even discriminatory.
In California with the entire procedure is such that evidence can be introduced by both sides and commonly is, but it's not unusual at all.

A psychiatric evidence can be introduced, sociological evidence, anything that in the opinion of the district attorney or the defense attorney might carry some weight with jury on the matter of penalty.
All of this evidence comes in and the only restrictions that I'm familiar with are those upon the prosecution, which cannot show certain things.
For example, you can't prove a crime, unless you can prove it beyond a reasonable doubt, and if you fail on that burden of proof, this would be as to prior crimes.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Well, it's certainly just the -- you could -- couldn't you just do some documentary evidence of a conviction?

turn.speaker: albert_w_harris_jr
turn.label: Mr. Albert W. Harris, Jr.
turn.text: Yes, you could do that.
What I had in mind, crimes that are not necessarily been reduced to a conviction, those could be proven too.
Or the defendant can prove his good record or whatever he thinks may be in his behalf, he can call witnesses, he call clergymen, psychiatrist, as I say, and a like (Voice Overlap).

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Is there a summing up to the jury by counsel for each side after the evidence on this penalty thing?

turn.speaker: albert_w_harris_jr
turn.label: Mr. Albert W. Harris, Jr.
turn.text: There is a very protracted, a very commonly, very protracted summing up, yes.
Full argument on both sides, and that at that point, the case is submitted to the jury.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Under what kind of instructions?

turn.speaker: albert_w_harris_jr
turn.label: Mr. Albert W. Harris, Jr.
turn.text: Well, the instruction is based basically upon the statute and in light of Mr. Amsterdam's remarks this morning about the lack of legislative determination of some of these problems.

I took a look at our statute, which is Section 190.1 of the Penal Code, rather long section, but it explains in a good deal of detail and nature of the penalty hearing, what kind of evidence can be introduced, and what the jury is suppose to do.
Now, they're not left in the dark by any means.

It's provided specifically that evidence may be produced at the penalty trial of the circumstances surrounding the crime, of the defendant's background and history, and of any facts and aggravation or mitigation of the penalty.

The determination and this is what they say to the jury and to the judge, this is what our legislature is so, the determination of the penalty of life imprisonment or death shall be in the discretion of the court or jury, trying the issue of fact on the evidence presented.
And the penalty fixed shall be expressly stated in the decision or verdict.
Now, I think it's clear that this does not anticipate any kind of an arbitrary judgment by the jury or the judge.
And he is to make the -- he or the juries to make the decision on the evidence presented.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: I asked too, what sort of instruction is there are given to the jury?

Does that judge normally just quote the statutory language that you read to us in reaching the decision, ladies and gentlemen of the jury, you should consider the circumstances of the crime, the defendant's background and history, any other facts or circumstances that may – whatever you read to us, does he say that?

turn.speaker: albert_w_harris_jr
turn.label: Mr. Albert W. Harris, Jr.
turn.text: That's essentially -- you may consider all of the evidence of those things that you've just mentioned, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: I'm just trying to remember what you read to us, but I --

turn.speaker: albert_w_harris_jr
turn.label: Mr. Albert W. Harris, Jr.
turn.text: It's phrased in terms of you may do this and you may do that, but basically it's the statutory language.
They're also told this, and this seems to be the heart of the petitioner's compliant.
However, it is not essential to your decision that you find mitigating circumstances on the one hand or evidence in aggravation of the offense on the other.
And this of course, is the more or less the -- represents the historical process that was discussed this morning.
They're also told this, and I think this excludes arbitrariness, and I think it excludes any of the things that we heard this morning.
Notwithstanding facts if any proved in mitigation or aggravation.
In determining which punishment shall be inflicted, you are entirely free to act according to you own judgment, conscience, and absolute discretion.
That verdict must express the individual opinion of each juror.

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: But you knew in California has some kind of standing also, maybe not enough if I understand?

turn.speaker: albert_w_harris_jr
turn.label: Mr. Albert W. Harris, Jr.
turn.text: I think that's true Mr. Justice Harlan, and I think perhaps we've too readily accept that the working proposition with the purposes of argument that there are no standards.

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: Well its absolute discretion of those imposing words?

turn.speaker: albert_w_harris_jr
turn.label: Mr. Albert W. Harris, Jr.
turn.text: That is -- those are two words, “absolute discretion.”

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: Is that a standard?

turn.speaker: albert_w_harris_jr
turn.label: Mr. Albert W. Harris, Jr.
turn.text: Well, it's a standard, as standards have developed in this kind of -- this (Voice Overlap).

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: (Voice Overlap) determination of what the legislature in California wants a jury to consider in this penalty phase of the trial, is it not?
To consider those – that statutory language, but ultimately in the end saying, it's entirely up to your discretion.
At least, that's a clear expression of the legislature that was their intent.
It wasn't done -- we don't have a situation that's been created by inadvertence, do you?

turn.speaker: albert_w_harris_jr
turn.label: Mr. Albert W. Harris, Jr.
turn.text: Certainly not, I can't imagine anymore specific statement of the legislative intent, and its clear recognition of the problem.
Now, it may not be the best solution, it may be better, it may be more logical, and it may be you've added symmetry to the law to say, you have to have mandatory death standards.

It may be that the – or standards for mandatory death sentences, it may be the Constitution requires that this Court move back 70 or 100 years, I suppose, and say well you have a death sentence that has to be a mandatory sentence with no discretion.
I find that hard to believe.

The decision of this Court over 70 years ago in Winston against the United States, today I think as well as any other -- anything I've ever read sums up the kind of considerations that I think any of us would agree, should be considered by a jury.

And I'm not talking about impermissible considerations, but you'll recall in Winston, the Court, this Court rejected a standard and held that a standard should not be implied, that death should be returned in the absence of mitigating circumstances.
Now, that's a standard of sorts, perhaps not a very specific one, but it is a standard.
This Court held that that did not express the intent of Congress, as manifest in the legislation.
But in discussing this, the Court pointed to some of the things that they thought should be considered, and would seem to me they should be considered today.

They said, how far considerations of age, sex, ignorance, illness, or intoxication of human passion or weakness, of sympathy or clemency, or the irrevocableness of an executed sentence of death or an apprehension that explanatory facts may exists, which have not been brought to light or any other consideration or whatever, should be allowed to wait in deciding the question whether the accused should or should not be capitally punished as committed by the act of Congress to the sound discretion of the jury and of the jury alone.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: That's a shaping of standards in a way, isn't it?

turn.speaker: albert_w_harris_jr
turn.label: Mr. Albert W. Harris, Jr.
turn.text: It's certainly a discussion of the factors, a statement listing of the factors Mr. Chief Justice.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Mr. Harris, your brief refers throughout to your standard in this procedure from this connection, doesn't it?

turn.speaker: albert_w_harris_jr
turn.label: Mr. Albert W. Harris, Jr.
turn.text: Yes it does, Your Honor, we've --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Standard in this procedure and you read somewhere in the language of this Court, from the Witherspoon case, as I read your brief.

That a juror that must choose between life imprisonment and capital punishment can do little more and must do nothing less to express the conscience of the community on the question of life and death.
That's what you quoted.

turn.speaker: albert_w_harris_jr
turn.label: Mr. Albert W. Harris, Jr.
turn.text: Yes, we quoted that.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: In connect with your standards, this is --

turn.speaker: albert_w_harris_jr
turn.label: Mr. Albert W. Harris, Jr.
turn.text: That's right, and we think in doing that, and the legislature in setting up the structure before doing that is not required to limit or restrict the discretion of the jury in anyway.
That essentially what standard means in this context, I think.
Certainly, it doesn't mean that anyone can be taken off the street and because the jury doesn't like him executed.
The ball of question arises only after a conviction of a capital offense and as to that the standards are very strict.

Historically, it's clear that the motivation here was to permit juries to draw distinctions in terms of humane and emotional considerations, and I think the thought in the minds of legislatures, that we can't list everything that might be material.
We cannot anticipate everything and we don't want to limit the discretion of the jurors.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Mr. Harris, do you allow judicial sentencing in pleas of guilty?

turn.speaker: albert_w_harris_jr
turn.label: Mr. Albert W. Harris, Jr.
turn.text: That's the standard, pardon me.
In death, in capital cases?

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: albert_w_harris_jr
turn.label: Mr. Albert W. Harris, Jr.
turn.text: Well, it's up to the defendant --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: What if he waives the jury?

turn.speaker: albert_w_harris_jr
turn.label: Mr. Albert W. Harris, Jr.
turn.text: He has the right to a jury, if he waives it we permit sentencing by the judge.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: What standards are provided for him?

turn.speaker: albert_w_harris_jr
turn.label: Mr. Albert W. Harris, Jr.
turn.text: None, except those that I have alluded to and supplied to the jury.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: But you do, I take it that if the judges sentencing, does he have a presentence report or not?

turn.speaker: albert_w_harris_jr
turn.label: Mr. Albert W. Harris, Jr.
turn.text: Well, in a capital case, I don't think a capital case would be handled exactly that way.
I think you would a more formal proceeding, that simply presentence report.
It would certainly be appropriate.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: But the judge would -- if he waives the jury trial of the sentence, part of it, why the judge would just try that on the same evidence, and the jury would hear it.

turn.speaker: albert_w_harris_jr
turn.label: Mr. Albert W. Harris, Jr.
turn.text: I believe that's true, yes sir, it would be -- that's not uncommon to have a trial before the judge on this issue of penalty, with the same evidence, with the same considerations in mind.

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: But may there also be a waiver just on the guilt -- plea of guilty to the crime, but then a jury trial on penalty?

turn.speaker: albert_w_harris_jr
turn.label: Mr. Albert W. Harris, Jr.
turn.text: Exactly, and that happens not infrequently.

And this -- it seems to be underlying, this whole argument of the petitioner here, the notion that unless there is uniform treatment handed out in convicted criminals, that there has been some violation of some provision of the Constitution.

Now, if there's one thing that's clear over the last half century, it is -- and this Court expressed very clearly and noted with approval, the practice of fitting the punishment not to the crime, but to the offender.

And it's not uncommon to have a whole variety of penalties handed out to a number of people, who have committed precisely the same crime, because you look to their background, you look to their role in the crime, you look to the nature of what each of those persons did.
And the Court has found nothing of constitutional dimensions in any way to bar this kind of procedure.

Now, we think that the leaving to the jury, the opportunity to extend mercy to a man who is convicted of a crime, potentially involved in a capital punishment, is simply an application of fitting the punishment to the offender and not to the crime.

Now, there's nothing -- not only is there nothing wrong with that, we think that's a -- and I think there's general agreement among people who know about these things that this what science has taught us, this is what everything we've learned has taught us.
And the capital sentencing is very typical of other sentencing in that respect in fitting the punishment to the offender.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: The guilty verdict, not in terms of the penalty, isn't that right?

turn.speaker: albert_w_harris_jr
turn.label: Mr. Albert W. Harris, Jr.
turn.text: Well, that's true Your Honor, but these are standards, and as I understand it, we're mitigating circumstances are listed as in the Model Penal Code, that is it, if you don't come under one of those, there's no way you can go to the jury and say this poor man should have his life spared, because he was good to his mother or something like and we can do that in California.
The only limitation on the defense in California is the ingenuity and the resourcefulness of the defense.
If he think of something that might appeal to one person on the jury, which is really all you need because you need unanimous jury.
He's free to urge it, and we see nothing wrong with that, and we don't see anything that necessarily or even logically would result in arbitrariness.
We think it's fair, and has worked pretty well over the years.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: But if there's a -- if the jury can't agree on that, does it automatically get life -- what happened?

turn.speaker: albert_w_harris_jr
turn.label: Mr. Albert W. Harris, Jr.
turn.text: Well, there are alternative provisions, if the jury disagrees, the judge can either impanel a jury or he can take the case and give him a life sentence.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: The judge can?

turn.speaker: albert_w_harris_jr
turn.label: Mr. Albert W. Harris, Jr.
turn.text: That judge can.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: But he cannot do more than that?

turn.speaker: albert_w_harris_jr
turn.label: Mr. Albert W. Harris, Jr.
turn.text: No, he can't do anymore than that.
Now, I think if look a little -- and I think we have to look at what is it that the states should do, and what should the federal government do, if what we do now is wrong, in terms of standards.
And I'm not talking about the single verdict, but in terms of standards, if what we're doing now is wrong, what is it that we should do?
Now, this is something that was covered in Witherspoon very carefully.
At least in noting what was not forbidden in Witherspoon, and giving the states guidelines as to what to do with these cases when they came back.

Now in listening to the argument today and in the reading the briefs, I haven't seen anything that's specifically points to the what the states could do to meet the standards that the petitioners submit have to be established.
They say if you look at the Model Penal Code, you'll find one you've limited defendants, there are things they can't urge.
And I don't think the people want that situation.
Even under the Model Penal Code you get down to formulations like this, it's easy to talk about standards, but what is the final formulation to a jury under the Model Penal Code.
Well, if found an aggravating circumstance, which could be -- for example he killed more than one person or he committed a felony in certain kinds and in connecting with the killing.

If you find an aggravating circumstance, you may return a death a sentence, you don't have to, you may, but then you have to determine whether the mitigating circumstances are not sufficiently substantial to call for leniency.
Now, what's the jury's told, that's the instruction.
And that would be my guess that a jury would go back and talk about these mitigating circumstances, and come back with a judge, and say well you told us what we could consider.
But how do we weigh each of these items, and how we determine when a particular circumstance is sufficiently substantial to call for leniency.
And I think the judge would have to say, “Well, you use your discretion, that's what then your sound discretion.”

So, where are you except that you have limited the defendant, and you set up a kind of an artificial and a structure that meets what the petitioners think all statutes should consist of and you ignored the experience of all the states that have the death sentence, and the United States Government, and for what end.
I think as the end would be a jury, still left with having to come to that fundamental decision.
Is this man going to die or is he going to live, and bare in mind that it's a man who has committed a capital offense and has been found guilty.
It's not someone off the street.
And one thing that has been emphasized in California, and there are number of cases that repeat this theme, and it runs through all of the death penalty cases.
We have many, many cases that deal only with penalty procedures, many appellate decisions.

And we've had countless retrials, solely on penalty, but a theme that runs through all of those decisions is this, you've got to convince the juror that it's his individual responsibility for that verdict.
When he goes out of that courtroom or he comes back with a verdict, it's his decision that this man should die.
He cannot leave the decision in someone else's hand.
You can't tell him the governor may grant clemency, because he's not supposed to think about such things.
If he mentions anything about parole, he's not supposed to worry about the parole board making a mistake.
It has to be his individual decision, and anything that has impeached that individual decision has been held bad in California.
Now, I think this is the -- the best way to administer this system if the death penalty is to continue and its validity asset is not an issue in this case.
If it's going to continue, and if you're going to conclude that not every member, not every person who commits murder one, should be executed.
Then, I think that the -- what we do is the fairest and the most rational, if I may use that word, way of concluding who should be executed that I have heard about.
And I think it's far preferable to the Model Penal Code, and I certainly think the legislature would reject notions of mandatory death sentences, in light of our whole experience.

Emphasizing this individual responsibility, I think gives the defendant the fair shake, and emphasizing to the jury that they have to consider the evidence, that they have to consider things that are produced in court, excludes, I think the possibility of any of the arbitrariness that's been mentioned here, earlier.

I have no doubt that a jury in California can't point to any decision, but I have no doubt that if a defendant thought that racial prejudice, status, class, position, or anything of that sort might possibly influence any single juror that he could ask the judge to please instruct them to get such things out of their minds.
I don't think those -- it's very unlikely that that would enter the minds of the jurors, but if there were any possibility, that could certainly be excluded.
They wouldn't have anymore of a standard, but should be telling you, you can't rely on these things.
That could be done, whether it could be done in Arkansas, I don't know, probably --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Mr. Harris, may I ask a question?

turn.speaker: albert_w_harris_jr
turn.label: Mr. Albert W. Harris, Jr.
turn.text: Yes, sir.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: We have vast reports about how many they are in death row in California.
Do you know how many they are?

turn.speaker: albert_w_harris_jr
turn.label: Mr. Albert W. Harris, Jr.
turn.text: Well, I think Mr. Amsterdam gave the figure of 85 to 90, which about thelast I heard.
I could get the precise figure for you, Your Honor.
But it's in that dimension.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Well, does that -- that seems to be a great many more than any in the other states.

turn.speaker: albert_w_harris_jr
turn.label: Mr. Albert W. Harris, Jr.
turn.text: Yes sir, it does.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Does that indicate that the more executions in California than in other states, percentage of according to the population?
How do you know?

turn.speaker: albert_w_harris_jr
turn.label: Mr. Albert W. Harris, Jr.
turn.text: I don't know about the statistics over time Your Honor.
I think that the accumulation at the moment is due to the stays over the last eight years.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: No doubt about that.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: But the stays have been applicable in great many other states too, have they not?

turn.speaker: albert_w_harris_jr
turn.label: Mr. Albert W. Harris, Jr.
turn.text: Yes, they have.
I think the last figure for jury verdicts of death that I saw was around 20.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Do you know whether been any effect on the amount of death sentences by dividing it up that you do between the original trial and the sentencing trial?

turn.speaker: albert_w_harris_jr
turn.label: Mr. Albert W. Harris, Jr.
turn.text: In terms of numbers, I don't Mr. Justice Black.
I have no information on that as far as the number.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: I wonder if you could supply us of that.

turn.speaker: albert_w_harris_jr
turn.label: Mr. Albert W. Harris, Jr.
turn.text: Certainly.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Maybe you could.

turn.speaker: albert_w_harris_jr
turn.label: Mr. Albert W. Harris, Jr.
turn.text: I can certainly try to and if I can get it out, I'd be glad to supply the Court.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Excuse Mr. Harris, I didn't understand.
You say 20 was the number of jury imposed?

turn.speaker: albert_w_harris_jr
turn.label: Mr. Albert W. Harris, Jr.
turn.text: I think that's the last figure I saw.
We --

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Who imposed the rest of them, of the 80 to 90?

turn.speaker: albert_w_harris_jr
turn.label: Mr. Albert W. Harris, Jr.
turn.text: Oh!
These go back, my gosh!
They go back ten years.
I mean for one year, there were some 20 (Voice Overlap).

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Oh!
In a single year?

turn.speaker: albert_w_harris_jr
turn.label: Mr. Albert W. Harris, Jr.
turn.text: In a single year.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Oh!
I see, yes.

turn.speaker: albert_w_harris_jr
turn.label: Mr. Albert W. Harris, Jr.
turn.text: And the 80 or the 90 or whatever it is goes -- I know of some that go back at least ten years.
So, I think that's a typical of the situation arising from stays.

And I think the submission of the petitioner here that this Court should, as far as the standards issue goes, as I understood Mr. Amsterdam this morning, in effect or it says it directly, set aside 505 approximately death sentences imposed throughout the United States.

For some defect, that it is also submitted cannot be corrected at least in terms of anything that we've been able to discuss here today and anything that you could tell to the states and to the Congress of the United States, in terms of this is what you should do, instead of what you've done.
I think this would be a very unfortunate situation.

And what the inability to articulate standards, I think doesn't show a lack of resourcefulness, but it shows us of the equalities that are involved here and the problems that are involved here are just such that we cannot reduce the problem to specific factors and way each any arbitrary manner.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Oh!
What -- what, as you experienced, I'm trying to pass it to the question.

turn.speaker: albert_w_harris_jr
turn.label: Mr. Albert W. Harris, Jr.
turn.text: Yes, sir.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Talk about standard, standard of course, the basic standard for any crime is the death admission of the crime.
Do you have a definition in your state for offensive rape?

Now, I could assume that the no purpose for standard, except to try divide up the types of crime, with reference to that atrocity, that ruthlessness, defendant's past experience, but can you think of any way as an Attorney General that you could that with just that simply saying that you've got to divide the crime of rape up into a number of different crimes of different degrees according to the circumstances?

turn.speaker: albert_w_harris_jr
turn.label: Mr. Albert W. Harris, Jr.
turn.text: I think you have to -- well, you would have to redefine the crime and say in effect will only allow the death penalty in a smaller class of cases.

As Your Honor said, in certain kinds of rape or by the same token in murder, and there's been no suggestion here that State of California has gone too far in defining first-degree murder or brought in cases that constitutionally can't be brought in.

And as I understand the argument, there would be no objection whatever, as far as this argument goes, if the State of California said humane considerations don't concern us, we'll impose a death penalty straight out, as to every man convicted of murder in the first degree.

And I can't believe that the Constitution of the United States requires that the people of California take that view, which 100 years ago might have been acceptable, but it's not acceptable today, simply for these artificial reasons.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
